title-group.article-title: The Factor Structure of the BASC-2 Behavioral and Emotional Screening System Teacher Form, Child/Adolescent

article-meta.aff: 2University of California, Santa Barbara, CA, USA

author-notes.corresp: Bridget V. Dever, Department of Educational Policy Studies, Georgia State University, College of Education, PO Box 3977, Atlanta, GA 30302-3977, USA Email: bdever@gsu.edu

abstract.p: The BASC-2 Behavioral and Emotional Screening System Teacher, Child/Adolescent Form (BESS Teacher Form C/A; Kamphaus & Reynolds, 2007) is a brief teacher-report rating scale designed to identify students who are at-risk for behavioral and emotional problems. The aim of this study was to describe the latent dimensions that underlie the responses to the BESS Teacher Form C/A. Exploratory factor analyses (EFA) and confirmatory factor analyses (CFA) across two random subsets of a nationally representative sample of 2,582 children aged 6 to 12 years suggested that the BESS Teacher Form C/A contains a four-factor latent structure consisting of Externalizing Problems, Internalizing Problems, School Problems, and Adaptive Skills.

kwd-group.kwd: BASC-2 Behavioral and Emotional Screening System

body.p: School-based, universal mental health screening has emerged as an efficient way to identify children at-risk for behavioral and emotional difficulties (Hunter et al., 2005). However, only 2% of schools employ screening techniques to identify children at-risk for mental health problems (Romer & McIntosh, 2005). Schools are unlikely to implement screening programs that they perceive as costly, time consuming, and/or difficult to implement (Kauffman, 1999). Therefore, brevity and ease of administration are important characteristics of a school-based screener for behavioral and emotional risk.

Screening measures should also provide reliable and valid information about core constructs that are associated with mental health problems among school-age children (Frick, Burns, & Kamphaus, 2009). Generally speaking, externalizing problems, internalizing problems, adaptive behavior/skills, and attention/learning problems have been identified as key constructs of children’s behavioral and emotional functioning (Edelbrock & Achenbach, 1980). Thus, it is desirable for any screening measure of children’s mental health risk to measure, at minimum, these four constructs (Kamphaus & Reynolds, 2007).

The BASC-2 Behavioral and Emotional Screening System (BESS; Kamphaus & Reynolds, 2007) has been developed to screen for behavioral and emotional risk. Although teacher-, parent-, and self-report forms are available, the present study focuses on the BESS Teacher Child/Adolescent Form (BESS Teacher) as factor analyses of the BESS parent-report (Dowdy, Chin, Twyford, & Dever, 2011) and BESS self-report (Dowdy, Twyford, et al., 2011) have been presented elsewhere. However, there are no published reports of the factor structure of the BESS Teacher form to date. The BESS Teacher was derived from the Behavior Assessment System for Children, 2nd edition, Teacher Rating Scale–Child and Adolescent Forms (BASC-2 TRS-C/A; Reynolds & Kamphaus, 2004). The 27 items for the BESS Teacher were selected from the 252 standardization items of the BASC-2 TRS-C/A using a test development model that emphasized theory and prior factor analytic work on the full BASC-2 TRS forms.

Based on factor analytic work conducted with the full BASC-2 TRS-C/A, four composites were generated: Adaptive Skills, Externalizing Problems, Internalizing Problems, and School Problems (Reynolds & Kamphaus, 2004). However, the BESS Teacher as an independent screening measure has not yet been subjected to similar factor analyses, and it is unclear whether it measures these or other important constructs. No independent, empirical evidence on the underlying factor structure of the BESS Teacher exists; however, it is important for practitioners and researchers to fully understand what constructs they are in fact measuring when using this new tool. The purpose of this study was to examine the factor structure of the BESS Teacher screening measure. We hypothesized that the instrument would contain a four-factor structure consistent with the full BASC-2 TRS-C/A.

sec.title: Sample
sec.p: Analyses were conducted with a sample of U.S. children from the standardization data for the BASC-2 TRS C/A (Reynolds & Kamphaus, 2004). This sample was representative of U.S. children in terms of sex, race and ethnicity, and clinical or special education status (Reynolds & Kamphaus, 2004). For the purpose of the present study, teacher responses to the 27 items that corresponded to the BESS Teacher were selected from the total item pool of the BASC-2 TRS C/A.

The sample for the present study included all teacher ratings from the standardization sample for the BASC-2 TRS Child Form only, which yielded a sample of 2,582 students aged 6 to 12 years. Student ethnicities as reported by caregivers were 59.6% White, 15.5% Black, 19.4% Hispanic, 2.5% Asian, and 3.1% Other. The sex distribution was approximately equal with 50.2% female. The full sample was randomly split into two equal subsamples (n = 1,291) to conduct the exploratory and confirmatory factor analyses with different subsamples.

sec.title: Measure
sec.p: The BESS Teacher (Kamphaus & Reynolds, 2007) is a screener for behavioral and emotional risk that consists of 27 items on a 4-point ordinal (i.e., never, sometimes, often, almost always) scale. The BESS Teacher requires no training and can be completed in approximately 5 min per student. A raw score is created by summing the responses to the behavior problem items and the reverse scores of the adaptive behavior items. The raw score is converted to a total T-score using a linear transformation, with higher scores reflecting greater risk. A T-score of 20 to 60 suggests a “normal” level of risk; 61 to 70 suggests an “elevated” level of risk; and scores of 71 or higher suggests an “extremely elevated” level of risk. Both gender-specific and overall norms are available for determining T-scores (Kamphaus & Reynolds, 2007). Presently, the single overall T-score is used and interpreted as there is no evidence of the underlying factor structure of the BESS Teacher.

Reliability and validity evidence is presented for the BESS Teacher based on a nationally representative sample (Kamphaus & Reynolds, 2007). Split-half reliability (0.96 to 0.97), test-retest reliability (0.91), and interrater reliability (0.71) estimates are good. Construct validity is indicated by correlations with other measures of emotional and behavior problems, including the Achenbach System of Empirically Based Assessment Teacher Report Form (Achenbach & Rescorla, 2001) total problems score (0.75), and Conners’ Teacher Rating Scale–Revised (Conners, 1997; 0.73-0.79). In addition, correlations with the Vineland-II Teacher Rating Form (Sparrow, Cicchetti, & Balla, 2006), a measure of adaptive behavior, are in the anticipated direction (−0.52 to −0.66). Finally, the BESS Teacher predicted the full BASC-2 TRS C/A (Reynolds & Kamphaus, 2004) Behavioral Symptoms Index with acceptable levels of sensitivity (0.80), specificity (0.97), positive predictive value (0.76), and negative predictive value (0.96).

sec.title: Exploratory Factor Analysis (EFA)
sec.p: Model solutions from one to five factors were analyzed with weighted least squares (WLS) EFA. The WLS estimation method was chosen due to its robustness against violations of multivariate normality and its appropriateness for ordinal scale data (Finney & DiStefano, 2006; Flora & Curran, 2004). Oblique promax rotation was used due to the likelihood of correlations between the factors. As examining eigenvalues in isolation often produces inaccurate, overfactored results (Costello & Osborne, 2005) and as there are difficulties with subjectively examining the scree plot for a natural turning point (Hayton, Allen, & Scarpello, 2004), the present study used a parallel analysis of the observed eigenvalues compared with the eigenvalues of randomly generated data (Horn, 1965). When the observed eigenvalue was greater than the eigenvalue generated by chance (p < .05), the factor was retained. Using this method, four factors were suggested.

Rotated factor loadings for the four-factor solution are presented in Table 1; item-level descriptive statistics are in Table 2. Factor loadings and cross-loadings greater than 0.32 were considered to be notable (Tabachnick & Fidell, 2001). Of the 27 items, four demonstrated cross-loadings greater than 0.32. Overall, the results supported a four-factor structure: Externalizing Problems, Internalizing Problems, School Problems, and Adaptive Skills. Content reviews suggested that the five-factor solution extracted a Somatic Problems scale (Headaches and Health Complaints) separate from Internalizing Problems, whereas the three-factor solution combined the School Problems and Adaptive Skills scales. However, as the four-factor model was both hypothesized and supported by the EFA results, this was the model retained for the confirmatory factor analyses (CFA).

caption.p: EFA Rotated Factor Loadings for the Four-Factor Solution
Standardized Factor Loadings for the Final Four-Factor Model CFA

fn.p: Note: All factor loadings significant at p < .001.

sec.title: CFA
sec.p: CFA models of the four-factor solution both with and without cross-loading items were compared using Mplus version 5.21 to verify the EFA results (Muthén & Muthén, 2007). The WLS estimation method was used again due to its robustness against violations of multivariate normality and its appropriateness for ordinal scale data (Finney & DiStefano, 2006; Flora & Curran, 2004). RMSEA values below 0.06 and CFI/TLI values above 0.95 indicate good model fit (Hu & Bentler, 1998).

The fit of the four-factor model without cross-loadings indicated an acceptable fit with the exception of the RMSEA statistic; χ2(318) = 1867.615, p < .001, CFI = 0.983, TLI = 0.982, RMSEA = .061. Next, a nested model was evaluated allowing for the four cross-loading items indicated in Table 1 (easily upset, negative, good study habits, well organized). A chi-square difference test supported the model that allowed for these cross-loaded items; Δχ2(4) = 301.781, p < .001. This four-factor model demonstrated a good fit: χ2(314) = 1565.834, CFI = 0.987, TLI = 0.985, RMSEA = .056 (factor loadings presented in Table 2). Alpha coefficients were calculated as a measure of internal consistency reliability for the final four factors and were found to be adequate (see Yang & Green, 2011 for discussion); Externalizing Problems (eight items): α = .919; Internalizing Problems (nine items): α = .827; School Problems (eight items): α = .935; Adaptive Skills (six items): α = .900. Correlations for the final EFA and CFA factor solutions are presented in Table 3.

caption.p: Correlations for Four-Factor Solution, EFA, and CFA

fn.p: Note: EFA = exploratory factor analysis; CFA = confirmatory factor analysis.

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: The purpose of the present study was to examine the factor structure for the BESS Teacher. The results of the EFA and CFA supported a four-factor structure consisting of: Externalizing Problems (e.g., disobeys, breaks rules), Internalizing Problems (e.g., sad, worries), School Problems (e.g., distracted, follows directions), and Adaptive Skills (e.g., gives suggestions, encourages others). These results are consistent with the core constructs of emotional and behavioral problems as identified by other sources (Edelbrock & Achenbach, 1980) as well as the item pool from which the BESS Teacher items were drawn (Kamphaus & Reynolds, 2007; Reynolds & Kamphaus, 2004).

The results of both the EFA and CFA supported a four-factor model that allowed for four items to cross-load onto two factors; future research should continue to consider potential cross-loadings to inform any subscales or instrument revisions that might take place. If the same four cross-loadings are found in future replications, it will be important to consider whether dropping these items prior to forming subscale scores is warranted. For example, inclusion of items that cross-load onto multiple subscales will inflate correlations between the subscales. However, due to the present use of only the full scale score in clinical decision making, it is suggested that these four items be retained until the present study is replicated. Although a four-factor model was suggested by the results, the Externalizing Problems, School Problems, and Adaptive Skills factors were highly correlated; therefore, future research is warranted to examine the discriminant validity of the factors. In addition, many of the factor loadings of the items were high, which may suggest the need for fewer items in future revisions of the instrument.

Discriminant and convergent validity evidence for the measure, and for potential subscale scores, is needed to further support score inferences. Researchers should also examine the predictive validity of the factors to determine if they are able to predict important outcomes such as special education referral or later diagnosis. Future studies including adolescent samples are also needed, as the screening measure was designed to be used among teachers of both children and adolescents. Despite the need for additional psychometric evidence, the present study provides an important first step to understanding the underlying factor structure of the BESS Teacher.

School-based practitioners considering screening as an efficient way to accomplish early identification must make fundamental decisions, including what core constructs they are interested in detecting. The present study provides preliminary evidence that the BESS Teacher measures four major constructs of behavior and emotionality including Externalizing Problems, Internalizing Problems, School Problems, and Adaptive Functioning. The inclusion of an internalizing problems factor may be of particular interest for school-based screening as symptoms of depression and anxiety are often overlooked through traditional referral mechanisms (Bradshaw, Buckley, & Ialongo, 2008). Despite the need for future research, current results indicate that this brief teacher-rated screener can provide valid information about the core constructs associated with mental health problems among school-age children.
